oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mirror of Nature, or Phrenological Development, Character and Talents
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside featuring a phrenological chart of murderer "John A. Murril" as performed by Dr. A. Crane, Professor of Phrenology, in 1844. It rates Murril's strongest traits under the categories of propensities, feelings, sentiments, perceptives, and reflectives. The broadside also provides an explanation of the chart.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Phrenology
Broadsides; Phrenology
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dr. A. Crane
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Phrenology was the study of skull features made popular in the early 19th Century. It is now largely considered to be a pseudo-science. The subject of this examination, "John A. Murril" is probably the infamous John A. Murrell, a colorful antebellum Tennessee outlaw.
